Nice video, but unfortunately I think the role of ADH in alcohol and caffeine induced diuresis is nothing but internet lore.

Review of scientific literature reveals more studies refuting an ADH-alcohol link than supporting it.  For example: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7573805.  In this paper's discussion, the authors state "In agreement with several previous studies, we did not observe suppression of plasma AVP [ADH] level during increased diuresis..."

And a literature review of the supposed link between ADH and caffeine reveals a grand total of 1 study:  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1692926 which concluded that ADH levels did not change in response to caffeine.

I don't know why this myth is so prevalent on the internet. Any if anyone knows of evidence to the contrary, feel free to reply.

UV exposure and genetic variants.

Their environments and exposure to sunlight over many thousands of years caused various physiological mutations, one including the intensity of skin pigment.  Other factors for the environment may have caused this genetic mutation as well.  Either way, the pigment of the skin, is a physiological product of the environment in which the species lives.  This includes mammals and certain reptiles.
Ultraviolet rays encourage the integument (skin) to produce vitamin D and a pigment called melanin via melanogenesis.  This is a product of instructions from DNA.

Light 'pollution'. Basically, the light from the city (houses, streetlights etc) raises the ambient light level around you. You know how your eyes adjust to the darkness so you can see? That happens with the ambient light in the city, you adjust to that, making the dimmer stars harder to see. If it's darker around you, your eyes become more sensitive to try and pick up dimmer light, making the relatively faint light of the stars more visible.

Great video. A slight error: ADH doesn't cause creation (transcription/translation) of aquaporins, but causes the relocation of aquaporins from inside cells to the cell membrane. So the total number of aquaporin molecules stays the same, but the amount available at the cell surface to conduct water increases.

Speedballing (aka powerballing) is the intravenous use of cocaine with heroin or morphine in the same syringe.

Alcohol & Caffeine together however are dangerous because caffeine can mask the effects of the alcohol. Caffeine will keep you feeling alert, prompting many drinkers to drink more alcohol because they aren't feeling drunk/buzzed. Thus consuming more than they normally would, possibly resulting in overdoses.

The most obvious danger is that the caffeine makes you feel wake and alert, thus reducing the perceived symptoms of the alcohol. In other words: even when you're totally drunk, you might feel rather sober. If you aren't fully aware of your alcohol intake or don't know your limit (or just generally act very irresponsibly under the influence), this can lead to all kinds of trouble from alcohol poisoning to dangerous accidents. But it's easier to say "don't mix em" than "you're an idiot".

To answer Jacqui Graham, adding salt to your drinking water does nothing to how "efficient" your body will absorb the water. Water is H2O, three specific atoms in one configuration. Think of it as a key. Where your body has a keyhole that H2O fits into, adding other things "around" it like salt (NaCl) does nothing to change it from being H2O. If it did, your key wouldn't fit that keyhole anymore.

Yes, it has a similar effect, just to differing degrees. The caffeine content in pop is (generally) much lower than that in your coffee, and as such it is less noticeable.

You thought right! The main emphasis here is that the proportion of water coming out in the urine between somebody who has a beverage with caffeine or alcohol in it will be more (in general) than that of somebody who drank the same amount of fluid, but without caffeine or alcohol. Of course there are many other factors to consider, such as current hydration and the fact that everybody's body conserves water differently and will be affect to different degrees by caffeine and alcohol.
